fdd:FDD.titleName: MXF File, OP1a, D-10 in Generic Container

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:fullName: MXF File, OP1a, D-10 in Generic Container

fdd:description.p: MXF OP1a file with Type D-10 Stream Specifications as defined in SMPTE 354M, Annex F: Type D-10 MPEG-2 4:2:2P@ML stream specifications for 525/60 and 625/50 essence in the Generic Container.

Key features of D-10 video include compression compliant with the MPEG-2 video standard (ISO/IEC 13818-2 [4:2:2P@ML]) - see also MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile and MXF File, OP1a, MPEG-2 in Generic Container. The basic stream constraints are:

ul.li: Bit rate: Up to 50 Mb/s constrained bytes per GOP
Maximum coded frame size: Up to 208.541 bytes net (30/1.001 I-frames/second); Up to 250.000 bytes net (25 I-frames/second)
Sampling frequency: Y: 13.5 MHz, R-Y/B-Y: 6.75 MHz

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: MXF OP1a file with D-10 video essence in the Generic Container.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: Generally employed in post-production or editing (middle phase) and in limited modes of dissemination (final phase).

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: MXF File, OP1a, MPEG-2 in Generic Container

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Audio and other essences of various types, not discussed at this time.

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: See the Library of Congress Recommended Formats Statement for format preferences for moving image content.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:adoption: Tools such as Apple's Compressor 4.4, AWS Elemental MediaConvert, Cube-Tec's MXF Legalizer all support D-10 in MXF but it's unclear about community use as of this writing in 2025. Comments welcome.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation:
See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
Accessibility Features
See MXF.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:externalDependencies: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:techProtection: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.

fdd:values.fdd:note: NARA File Format Preservation Plan ID has an entry for general MPEG-2 Video, https://www.archives.gov/files/lod/dpframework/id/NF00337.ttl, but this is not specific to D-10. See also MXF and MXF_OP1a for NARA File Format Preservation Plan ID.
Wikidata https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q28919138 entry for IMX but it seems to mostly refer to the physical cassette rather than the video compression. Comments welcome. See also MXF and MXF_OP1a.

fdd:notes.fdd:general: Note that "D-10" or "D10" can refer to both the video encoding as well as the physical (0.5-in) tape in cassettes that carries the essence data. D-10 is also called MPEG IMX by Sony. See also Material Exchange Format FAQ (link via Internet Archive) which states "IMX is a brand name from Sony and is used to denote their products that support “MPEG D10 format and/or D10 Streaming (SMPTE 365M and 356M) at 50 Mb/s rates (and 30, 40 Mb/s too for some products). For example, the Sony MSW-2000 series is an IMX branded VTR that supports the MPEG D10 tape format. D10 Streaming is a constrained form of I-frame only MPEG2 specifying that each I-Frame has the same exact number of bytes of data. The format is very VTR friendly. This MPEG format is also the compression standard carried in SDTI-CP links (SMPTE 331M). IMX is not a file format or a compression format -- it is a brand mark." The 2007 SONY MPEG IMX Family brochure provides some helpful information about the MPEG IMX format (in addition to SONY supporting products).

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: See MXF, MXF_OP1a and MPEG-2, 4:2:2 Profile.
